Consider the function f(x) = 4x - x^2. We are going to use the limit definition of f'(a) to find several different values of the derivative function and explore patterns that we find.
Recall that the limit definition of f'(1) is f'(1) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} and thus we need to determine an expression for f(1+h), as well as for f(1+h) - f(1).
Using the given formula f(x) = 4x - x^2, which of the following is the simplest possible expression for f(1+h)?
f(1+h) = 4(1+h)-(1+h)^2 f(1+h)= 3 + 4h - h^2 f(1+h) = 3 + 6h + h^2 f(1+h) = 3 + 2h - h^2
In addition, which of the following is the simplest possible expression for f(1+h) - f(1)?
f(1+h) - f(1) = 4(1+h)-(1+h)^2 - 3 f(1+h) - f(1) = 4h - h^2 f(1+h) - f(1) = 6h + h^2 f(1+h) - f(1) = 2h - h^2
Next, apply the limit definition of the derivative by substituting the simplest possible expression for f(1+h)-f(1) in the space provided:
f'(1)= \displaystyle \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0} $dq_x1 = ($$f(1+h) - $$f(1))/h
By factoring the numerator and simplifying, we see that
f'(1)= \displaystyle \lim_{h \to 0} $simp_x1 = ($$f(1+h) - $$f(1))/h
Finally, evaluate the limit by letting h \to 0 to determine the value of f'(1):
f'(1) = $$fp(1)
